Problem:
Consider a complex function \\( z(t) = e^{At} \\) where \\( A \\) is a constant complex matrix. We evaluate the impact of the Fourier Transform and its inverse defined by the function \\( F(z) = \\int_{-\\infty}^{\\infty} e^{-2\\pi i \\xi t} z(t) dt \\) and \\( F^{-1}(z) = \\int_{-\\infty}^{\\infty} e^{2\\pi i \\xi t} z(t) dt \\).

If at time \\( t_1 \\), an intervention which is represented by another transform, say \\( G(z) = \\int_{-\\infty}^{\\infty} e^{-3\\pi i \\xi t} z(t) dt \\), is applied, will the final state at t = T only depend on the dynamics represented by \\( A \\), and not on the initial Fourier Transform?
Explanation: The intervention with \\( G(z) \\) adds a new dimension to the transformation, mixing frequency components in another manner. The final state at t = T will therefore depend not just on \\( A \\) but also on how \\( F(z) \\) and \\( G(z) \\) interact and alter the trajectory in the complex-frequency domain.
